channel.title: Campeonato on Simba Tango
channel.description: Recent content in Campeonato on Simba Tango

item.title: Campeones mundiales de tango salon 2010: Maria Ines Bogado & Sebastian Jimenez
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description:
This is no longer news, of course, but I am finally catching up after being on vacations with no internet access (which was actually very nice!).

My congratulations to these beautiful dancers (that I wrote about before)!

The jury consisted of Eduardo Arquimbau, Julio Duplaa, Julio Balmaceda, el Nene Masci, Pablo Inza, Ana Maria Schapira y Javier Rodríguez, according to 2xtango.com. I appears that some find it shocking that someone so young won the championship (Sebastian is 18). Last year it was shocking that the winners were foreign. I have my doubts about the concept of a championship myself, but I see it mainly as a chance for young dancers to make a name for themselves. And once again the jury chose two very worthy winners! Congratulations!

item.title: Congratulations! | ¡Felicitaciones!
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description:
The final of the campeonato de la ciudad (formerly campeonato metropoletano) was last night, and I am happy to see that Sebastián & Ines did well. Felicitaciones, chicos!

The full list of the winners  is available here. The winners are:

  • Alberto Markus & Ana María Polito (“Tango Salon” Senior)

  • Lucas Carrizo & María Paula Tejeda (“Tango Salón” Adulto)

  • Ariel Manzanares & Daniela Cerquides (“Milonga”)

  • Sebastián Jimenez & María Inés Bogado (“Vals”)

Photo stolen from Festivales de Buenos Aires

2xtango got video and more information:

According to 2xtango, the members of the jury were Olga Besio, Elina Roldan, Silvia Toscano, El Flaco Dany, Julio Duplaa, El Turco Swaya and Eduardo Arquimbau.

item.title: Japan Update
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description:
Finally some videos of the new champions. Bear over with the person holding the camera not being able to keep still, and make sure you get the milonga at the end. The Argentine newspaper Clarin has a short interview with them.

I mentioned in a previous post that Japan was important because of the collectors of tango music there, and Royce recently posted several posts (here, here and here [UPDATE: She added part 4, part 5 and part 6] ) on this topic that are well worth a read. I only have a couple of the CTA series myself, but they are great and I am looking for more.

Mari has a nice post about how the Japanese tea seremony can teach us about tango that I really enjoyed.

Finally, this seems to be a good placeto mention a great Japanese film about dancing, but not about tango. It is called Shall we dance. I never bothered to watch the Hollywood remake, and I suggest you don’t either. Go for the original. The Japanese cultural resistance to couple dancing only makes the dancing of the campeones more touching.

item.title: Big in Japan
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description:
by  skyseeker

Seeing the reactions from many  after the Japanese couple Hiroshi & Kyoko Yamao won the mundial de tango salón as the first non-Argentines, it seems many in the tango world are unaware of the long traditions of tango in Japan. Or maybe some practice selective memory…

Todotango has an interesting article on the rise of tango in Japan. While the tradition is certainly shorter in terms of years since the first impact than in Europe (Megata’s first contact with tango was in Paris in the 1920s), it does not lack much, and in a way it represents a tradition closer to the original than in Europe. And thanks in great deal to the Japanese collectors, we can today enjoy reissues of long lost treasures from the Argentine masters.

El barón Megata, en el año veinte, se tomaba el buque con rumbo a París, y allí, entre los tangos y el "dolce far niente", el japonesito se hizo bailarín. Flaco y bien plantado. Pinta milonguera. De empilche a lo duque, aun siendo barón. Bailó con Pizarro, y una primavera empacó los discos y volvió a Japón. Y así llevó el tango a tierra nipona, donde gratarola lo enseñó a bailar. Cuentan que Megata no cobraba un mango, por amor al tango y por ser bacán. No sólo enseñaba cortes y quebradas, también daba clases de hombría de bien; junaba de noches y de madrugadas, piloteaba aviones y más de un beguén. Y tal vez ahora, que está aquí presente, mientras una Sony nos pasa "Chiqué", alguien, allá en Tokio, elegantemente, baile a lo Megata sin saber quién fue. > > _Luis Alposta: _[_A lo Megata_](http://www.todotango.com/english/las_obras/letra.aspx?idletra=1060) > >

So in a sense, that it was a Japanese couple that broke the line of all Argentine campeones mundiales, should come as no surprise. From my own anecdotal experience, the Japanese tend to be excellent dancers.

A friend of mine once half jokingly said that the quality of the Japanese/Asian dancers fits in well with the Japanese (and later other Asian countries) way of manufacturing, and the results thereof that hit post war Europe and USA. First copy. Then improve.

item.title: Campeones mundiales de tango salon 2009: Hiroshi & Kyoko Yamao (JP)
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description:
I have wondered whether the Argentine would ever select a non-argentine couple to win the tango salon category. Now I know, the fabulous Japanese couple Hiroshi & Kyoko just won the first prize! Great dancers and great people! Felicitaciones!!!

UPDATE:

2xtango got pictures and video from the last ronda with Hiroshi and Kyoko and a nice post about the winners. Also Hiroshi and Kyoko have some pictures at their blog (machine translated from Japanese). There is also a short notice in La Nacion.

UPDATE 2:

YYQuest dug up a video of the new and old champions, so I substitute the illustration video for that. The original video here:

item.title: ¡Mucha mierda en el mundial!
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description:
by  Simba tango

Tonight is the night of the final of the mundial (world championship) of tango salon. While I always found the idea of a competition in social dancing somewhat absurd, it happens that for the last couple of years several friends have been among the finalists, and that made it all more interesting.

It all starts at 1900 local time, and rumors have it there will be live broadcast, and I will try to catch it.

Good luck, my friends!

¡Mucha mierda, chicos!

UPDATE: No luck with the webcast, unfortunately, only football there…

item.title: Cristhian Sosa & Lida Montovani
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description:
Wow! First place both in milonga and vals! I am impressed, but not surprised. They were  in a different class entirely as far as I could judge from the videos posted over at 2xtango.

Felicitaciones!

Here they are performing at La Viruta. A milonga and a vals, of course.

item.title: Confiteria La Ideal en BBC
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description:
Another good documentary about tango. I enjoyed it a lot. Some of the interesting scenes are available on youtube, but the documentary itself was quite hard to get hold of. As far as I could determine, it is not available for sale, not even on ebay, so you better know one of them pirates or use your imagination ;-)

I am quite impressed by how ordinary dancers are able to express what tango means to them. I always find it hard to describe what in tango I love so much or why I came to be obsessed with tango.

And it made me long for Buenos Aires. A lot. And that hurt. But it was still a good experience, a tango experience I suppose.

item.title: More on less
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description:
I just read an interview with this year’s campeones, Daniel Nacucchio & Cristina Sosa (congratulations, and nice to see Neri & Yanina did well also :-) - Well, he quoted old milonguero wisdom:

El que menos hace, a veces es el que hace más

Which means something like, the one who does less, sometimes is the one that does more. (Forgive my translation, neither Spanish nor English is my native language).  Exactly.

PS: The interview was in the excellent B.A. Tango, which you can subsctribe to by sending an email to  abatango@yahoo.com with the subject line “Suscripción”.
